question: 5 (d)
statement_html:
Consider an internet with six sites. The stochastic matrix describing the behaviour of a web surfer (with damping factor zero) is

\[\begin{aligned} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ \frac12 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 \\ \frac12 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \\ 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 1 & 0 & \frac12 \\ 0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

(d) Each set below contains the absolute values of the eigenvalues of either P or (1/2)P + (1/2)Q. Check your guess for which list is which below and give a reason for your choice.

{1.00, 0.42, 0.19, 0.19, 0.10, 0.25 are the values: for P ❏, for (1/2)P + (1/2)Q ❏

{1.00, 0.85, 0.38, 0.38, 0.21, 0.50 are the values: for P ❏, for (1/2)P + (1/2)Q ❏
statement_raw:
Consider an internet with six sites. The stochastic matrix describing the behaviour of a web surfer (with damping factor zero) is

:<math>
P = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
\frac12 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 \\
\frac12 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \\
0 & \frac13 & 0 & 1 & 0 & \frac12 \\
0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & \frac12 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

'''(d)''' Each set below contains the absolute values of the eigenvalues of either ''P'' or ''(1/2)P + (1/2)Q''. Check your guess for which list is which below and give a reason for your choice.

''{1.00, 0.42, 0.19, 0.19, 0.10, 0.25'' are the values: for ''P'' &#x274f;, for ''(1/2)P + (1/2)Q'' &#x274f;

''{1.00, 0.85, 0.38, 0.38, 0.21, 0.50'' are the values: for ''P'' &#x274f;, for ''(1/2)P + (1/2)Q'' &#x274f;
